awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Isolating Specific Appliance Energy Usage from Whole Building Energy Consumption
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will further develop the IBUCS' Utility Accountant electrical load disaggregation system and conduct performance trials in small commercial settings. Utility ratepayers need granular information to more effectively identify and mitigate inefficient appliances and activities. The new generation of smart electric meters currently being deployed for automated reading and time of use pricing are not be able to provide this level of detail. The signal processing algorithms evaluated during the Phase I study accurately isolate and quantify the power used by individual appliances from the aggregate power signal of the many appliances present on a leg or circuit. In the proposed project, additional enhancements will be made to the load disaggregation algorithm that will significantly improve system accuracy and reliability. Ratepayers will access a secure webpage to view their cost to operate specific appliances in their building or groups of buildings. The granular perspective provided will enable end-users to (1) calculate their own investment return periods for equipment repairs and upgrades, (2) develop data driven best practices for energy conservation, and (3) ensure that cost reductions are maintained over the long term.

The broader impact will occur when the technology is deployed throughout the residential and commercial segments as part of a new generation of smart meters. Commercially-available systems that directly monitor multiple specific loads are more expensive by an order of magnitude and inherently more difficult to install and maintain. Providing appliance specific load information has the potential to transform ratepayers' ability to conserve energy. The intended outcome of this Phase II project is to create an easy-to-use tool that will continually educate small business or franchise operators to reduce energy consumption. Nationally, Quick Serve businesses (i.e. fast-food restaurants, gas stations, and minimarts) account for ~10% of commercial buildings but are generally underserved by energy management companies due to their small size. IBUCS will provide a value-added service to the property manager through an energy management company that serves this segment.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Web-based monitoring of electricity consumption and demand (average power) has become commonplace for commercial buildings, but the same techniques are not cost-effective for monitoring individual appliances. NILM, non-intrusive load monitoring, is an approach that minimizes the numbers of sensors required—using software to identify and track specific loads. Researchers at LoadIQ have applied machine learning techniques to isolate, cluster, and classify specific loads at a resolution and accuracy that is sufficient for commercial energy applications.

The conventional approach for energy services companies in tracking specific end-uses or electrical loads has been to use temporary data loggers, or multi-channel submeters with sensors directly measuring voltage and current on the relevant circuits at the electrical panel.  Given the number of circuits and variety of loads in commercial buildings, deploying sensors for each circuit breaker is cost prohibitive. Installation of the sensors is also time-consuming, since each circuit has to be manually mapped to its connected loads. Recent advancements in cloud-computing and decreasing hardware and communication costs have set the stage for NILM solutions. LoadIQ’s primary focus has been on performance—namely, accuracy and consistency.

While several NILM approaches use electrical load signatures to signify a specific load, LoadIQ found tracking load transitions to be more effective in three-phase commercial environments. LoadIQ developed its own NILM hardware, EI.X Series Monitor™ (“EI.X”), which uses kHz-level sampling to identify loads that turn on or off, including changes to their steady state profile. Transitions are clustered, and the sum of these transitions is compared to the total circuit power calculated from actual current (A) and power (V) measurements. LoadIQ, in tests with the Electrical Power Research Institute (EPRI), disaggregated 90% of the total energy with an overall accuracy of 87%.  In subsequent commercial deployments, the performance varied based on the number and variability of the loads on a given circuit.  In most cases, LoadIQ captures the top five contributing loads for energy (kWh) and demand (kW) on each channel. EI.X configurations range from 6 to 24 total channels (i.e., 2 – 8 three-phase lines).

Another aspect of performance is labeling, or identifying a load by its name, type, or end-use. LoadIQ’s software platform—Enable.EI™--includes a web-based tool to apply labels to individual loads, or to combine loads into groups. Energy professionals may be interested in seeing data for load sub-components across three phases for fault detection/diagnostics, for example. In other applications, loads may be combined into end-use categories (e.g., HVAC, cooking, cooling). Automating the application of labels continues to be an active research area. LoadIQ will introduce a recommendation engine to assist customers with both labeling and grouping. Researchers are also integrating runtime data from building controls, where available, to automate labeling with names already used in building controls software.

LoadIQ, with funding from its founders, private investors, and the National Science Foundation, is poised to change the energy services ecosystem with a commercial NILM solution. The company primarily supports energy services companies, and even some utilities, with energy and cost-saving applications that require granular energy intelligence. For more information, please visit www.loadiq.com.  

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2015
Modified by: Hampden Kuhns
